name: IhrisParametersRemoteConfig
title: iHRIS Parameters Remote Config
description: Configuration Parameters to be loaded from a remote file for iHRIS.

element.short: Operation Request or Response
element.definition: This resource is a non-persisted resource used to pass information into and back from an [operation](operations.html). It has no other use, and there is no RESTful endpoint associated with it.
element.comment: The parameters that may be used are defined by the OperationDefinition resource.

element.short: Logical id of this artifact
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.short: Metadata about the resource
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.short: Language of the resource content
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Operation Parameter
element.definition: A parameter passed to or received from the operation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
A parameter must have one and only one of (value, resource, part)
constraint.expression: (part.exists() and value.empty() and resource.empty()) or (part.empty() and (value.exists() xor resource.exists()))
constraint.xpath: (exists(f:resource) or exists(f:part) or exists(f:*[starts-with(local-name(.), 'value')])) and not(exists(f:*[starts-with(local-name(.), 'value')])) and exists(f:resource))) and not(exists(f:*[starts-with(local-name(.), 'value')])) and exists(f:part))) and not(exists(f:part) and exists(f:resource))

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: Indication of the reason the entity signed the object(s)
element.definition: An indication of the reason that the entity signed this document. This may be explicitly included as part of the signature information and can be used when determining accountability for various actions concerning the document.
element.comment: Examples include attesting to: authorship, correct transcription, and witness of specific event. Also known as a "Commitment Type Indication".

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: An indication of the reason that an entity signed the object.

element.short: When the signature was created
element.definition: When the digital signature was signed.
element.comment: This should agree with the information in the signature.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Who signed
element.definition: A reference to an application-usable description of the identity that signed  (e.g. the signature used their private key).
element.comment: This should agree with the information in the signature.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The party represented
element.definition: A reference to an application-usable description of the identity that is represented by the signature.
element.comment: The party that can't sign. For example a child.
element.requirements: used when the signature is on behalf of a non-signer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The technical format of the signed resources
element.definition: A mime type that indicates the technical format of the target resources signed by the signature.
element.comment: "xml", "json" and "ttl" are allowed, which describe the simple encodings described in the specification (and imply appropriate bundle support). Otherwise, mime types are legal here.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

element.short: The technical format of the signature
element.definition: A mime type that indicates the technical format of the signature. Important mime types are application/signature+xml for X ML DigSig, application/jose for JWS, and image/* for a graphical image of a signature, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

element.short: The actual signature content (XML DigSig. JWS, picture, etc.)
element.definition: The base64 encoding of the Signature content. When signature is not recorded electronically this element would be empty.
element.comment: Where the signature type is an XML DigSig, the signed content is a FHIR Resource(s), the signature is of the XML form of the Resource(s) using  XML-Signature (XMLDIG) "Detached Signature" form.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
